text: Revenue of $25.2 billion, representing a 3% year-over-year increase.
Net income of $7.8 billion, a 10% year-over-year increase.
Earnings per share (EPS) of $0.90, an 11% year-over-year increase.
Deposits stood at $1.9 trillion, showing a modest increase quarter-over-quarter.
Common Equity Tier 1 (CET1) ratio was 11.9%, which is 240 basis points above the regulatory minimum.
The quarterly dividend was increased by 9%.
Robust liquidity is maintained with average Global Liquidity Sources (GLS) of $859 billion.
Return on average common equity was 11.2%.
Return on average tangible common equity was 15.5%.
Return on average assets was 0.99%.
Net income of $7.8B; diluted earnings per share of $0.90; Return on Equity (ROE) of 11.2%, and Return on Tangible Common Equity (ROTCE) of 15.5%.
Revenue, net of interest expense, of $25.2B increased by $0.7B, or 3%, compared to 3Q22.
Net interest income (NII) of $14.4B ($14.5B FTE) increased $0.6B, or 4%, driven by higher interest rates and loan growth.
Noninterest income of $10.8B increased by $51MM, as higher sales and trading revenue and asset management fees more than offset lower other income.
Provision for credit losses was $1.2B.
Net reserve build of $303MM, compared to net reserve builds of $378MM in 3Q22 and $256MM in 2Q23.
Net charge-offs (NCOs) of $931MM increased compared to 3Q22 and 2Q23, but remained below 4Q19 pre-pandemic levels.
The net charge-off ratio of 35 bps increased by 15 bps from 3Q22 and 2 bps from 2Q23.
Noninterest expense of $15.8B increased by $0.5B, or 3%, vs. 3Q22, and declined by $0.2B, or 1%, vs. 2Q23.
The balance sheet remained strong, with average deposits of $1.88T and average loans and leases of $1.05T being relatively flat compared to 2Q23.
Common Equity Tier 1 capital of $194B increased by $4B from 2Q23.
The Common Equity Tier 1 ratio of 11.9% increased by 29 bps from 2Q23 and is 240 bps above the regulatory minimum effective October 1, 2023.
Average Global Liquidity Sources stood at $859B.
Paid $1.9B in common dividends and repurchased $1.0B of common stock.
The quarterly common dividend per share was increased by 9%.
Consumer Banking added over 200,000 net new checking accounts, marking the 19th consecutive quarter of growth, and added 1.1 million new credit card accounts.
Consumer Banking reached a record 3.8 million consumer investment accounts, with $51 billion in net client flows since 3Q22.
It was the 35th consecutive quarter of net new Small Business checking account growth.
Global Wealth & Investment Management added approximately 7,000 net new relationships across Merrill and Private Bank, a 20% YoY increase.
Assets under management flows were $44B since 3Q22, and over 39,000 new bank accounts were opened, up 6% YoY.
Global Banking added more than 1,900 new clients year-to-date while deepening relationships with existing clients.
Business Lending revenue increased 26% YoY to $2.6B, and Global Transaction Services revenue reached $8.8 billion YTD, up 20% YoY.
Ranked #3 in investment banking fees, growing market share by 78 bps compared to 3Q22.
Global Markets reported the highest year-to-date sales and trading revenue in over a decade and a record 3Q for Equities sales and trading revenue.
Global Markets saw record average loans of $131 billion, up 9% YoY, and experienced zero trading loss days year-to-date in 2023.
Digital adoption rates are strong across segments: 74% in Consumer, 83% in Merrill, 92% in Private Bank, and 75% in Global Banking.
There are 46 million digital active users, who have logged in 3.2 billion times.
Client engagement highlights include 170 million Erica interactions (+27% YoY), 1.6 million secure client-advisor messages in Merrill (+22% YoY), and 813,000 CashPro App sign-ins (+41% YoY).
Digital volumes show significant growth, with 323 million Zelle transactions (+27% YoY), 74% of GWIM checks deposited via automated channels, and $192 billion in CashPro App payments (+16% YoY).
In 3Q23, revenue increased by $0.7B and expenses increased by $0.5B.
Year-to-date 2023 revenue for Global Markets was $15.4B, an increase of 8%, and net income was $4.0B, an increase of 10%.
The international franchise has extensive coverage, spanning over 80% of international GDP and over 90% of both equity market capitalization and the investment banking fee pool.
The bank holds top-tier rankings, including #3 in global IB fee ranking and #1 for Developed Europe and Emerging EMEA Research Providers.
The CET1 ratio under the Standardized approach increased by 29 basis points from 2Q23 to 11.9% in 3Q23.
CET1 capital reached $194B, an increase of $4B from 2Q23, driven by net income but partially offset by capital distributions.
Standardized Risk-Weighted Assets (RWA) decreased by $5B from 2Q23 to $1,634B.
Book value per share improved by 9% from 3Q22 to $32.65, and tangible book value per share improved by 12% from 3Q22 to $23.79.
Average Global Liquidity Sources were $859B, down $8B (or 1%) from 2Q23.
Bank of America is ranked #1 in U.S. Retail Deposit Market Share.
Deposits in excess of loans, which peaked at $1.1T in 4Q21, remained elevated at over $0.8T in 3Q23.
In 3Q23, excess deposits were stored in a mix of 53% held-to-maturity (HTM) securities and 47% in cash and available-for-sale (AFS) securities.
Cash levels of $352B in 3Q23 remain well above pre-pandemic levels ($157B in 3Q19).
AFS securities are mostly hedged with floating rate swaps, resulting in a duration of less than 0.5 years.
The HTM securities book has declined by $80B since its peak in 3Q21.
The blended yield on cash and securities continued to improve in 3Q23, reaching 3.34%, which is 178 basis points above the total deposit rate of 1.55%.
Net Interest Income (NII) and net interest yield improved in 3Q23 compared to both 3Q22 and 2Q23.

Net interest income (NII) for 3Q23 was $14.4B ($14.5B on a fully taxable-equivalent basis), a year-over-year increase of $0.6B, driven by higher interest rates and loan growth, which was partially offset by lower deposit balances.
Compared to 2Q23, NII increased by $0.2B due to higher asset yields, increased NII from Global Markets activity, and an extra day of interest accrual, partially offset by higher deposit costs.
The net interest yield was 2.11%, up 5 basis points both year-over-year and from 2Q23.
Excluding Global Markets, the net interest yield was 2.64%.
As of September 30, 2023, a +100 bps parallel upward shift in the interest rate yield curve is estimated to benefit NII by $3.1B over the next 12 months.
Noninterest expense of $15.8B in 3Q23 increased by $0.5B (3%) compared to 3Q22, driven by investments in people and technology, and higher FDIC expense.
Compared to 2Q23, noninterest expense declined by $0.2B (1%), primarily due to lower litigation expense ($76MM in 3Q23 vs. $276MM in 2Q23).
4Q23 expense could potentially include an accrual of approximately $1.9B for the FDIC special assessment rule for uninsured deposits of failed banks.
Total net charge-offs of $931MM increased by $62MM from 2Q23, with consumer charge-offs increasing by $84MM and commercial charge-offs decreasing by $22MM.
The credit card loss rate was 2.72% in 3Q23, compared to 2.60% in 2Q23, remaining below the pre-pandemic rate of 3.03% in 4Q19.
The net charge-off ratio of 0.35% increased by 2 bps from 2Q23 and remained below the pre-pandemic level of 0.39% in 4Q19.
Provision for credit losses was $1.2B, which included a net reserve build of $303MM, primarily driven by credit card.
The allowance for loan and lease losses was $13.3B, representing 1.27% of total loans and leases.
Nonperforming loans (NPLs) increased by $0.7B from 2Q23 to $4.8B, mainly driven by Commercial Real Estate.
Commercial reservable criticized utilized exposure increased by $2.3B from 2Q23 to $23.7B, also primarily driven by Commercial Real Estate.
Net income of $2.9B decreased 7% from 3Q22, as strong revenue growth was offset by higher provision for credit losses and noninterest expense.
Pretax, pre-provision income of $5.2B increased 9% from 3Q22, marking the 10th consecutive quarter of operating leverage.
Revenue of $10.5B increased 6% from 3Q22, driven by improved NII from higher interest rates and loan balances.
Provision for credit losses was $1.4B, compared to $0.7B in 3Q22, with a net reserve build of $486MM in 3Q23.
Net charge-offs of $911MM increased by $399MM, driven by credit cards, but remained below pre-pandemic levels.
Noninterest expense of $5.3B increased 3% from 3Q22, due to investments and higher FDIC expense.
Average deposits of $980B decreased by 8% from 3Q22, with 57% of deposits in checking accounts.
Average loans and leases of $311B increased by 5% from 3Q22.
Combined credit/debit card spend of $225B increased 3% from 3Q22.
Record consumer investment assets of $387B grew by 28% from 3Q22, driven by record client flows.
10.7 million clients are enrolled in Preferred Rewards, up 7% from 3Q22, with a 99% annualized retention rate.
Net income of $1.0B decreased 13% from 3Q22, with a pretax margin of 26% and strong organic client activity.
Revenue of $5.3B decreased 2% compared to 3Q22, driven by lower NII, partially offset by higher asset management fees.
Noninterest expense of $4.0B increased 4% vs. 3Q22, due to investments in the business and strategic hiring.
Client balances of $3.6T increased 9% from 3Q22, driven by higher market valuations and positive net client flows, including AUM flows of $14B in 3Q23.
Average deposits of $292B decreased by 14% from 3Q22.
Average loans and leases of $219B decreased by 2% from 3Q22.
Nearly 7,000 net new relationships were added across Merrill and Private Bank in 3Q23, and over 39,000 new bank accounts were opened.
83% of GWIM households and relationships are digitally active across the enterprise.
Net income of $2.6B increased 26% from 3Q22, with pretax, pre-provision income of $3.4B up 16%.
Revenue of $6.2B increased 11% vs. 3Q22, driven primarily by higher NII and leasing revenue.
Total Corporation investment banking fees (excluding self-led) of $1.2B increased 2% from 3Q22, improving market share by 78 bps.
Provision for credit losses reflected a benefit of $119MM, driven by net loan paydowns.
Noninterest expense of $2.8B increased 6% from 3Q22, due to continued business investments and higher FDIC expense.
Average deposits of $504B increased by 2% from 3Q22.
Average loans and leases of $376B decreased by 2% from 3Q22, reflecting paydowns and lower client demand.
Net income of $1.2B increased 17% from 3Q22. Excluding net DVA, net income was $1.3B, also up 17%.
Revenue of $4.9B increased 10% from 3Q22, driven primarily by higher sales and trading revenue.
Sales and trading revenue of $4.4B increased 8% from 3Q22.
FICC revenue increased 6% to $2.7B, driven by improved trading in credit and mortgage products.
Equities revenue increased 10% to $1.7B, driven by an increase in client financing activities.
Noninterest expense of $3.2B increased 7% vs. 3Q22, due to investments in the business.
Average VaR was $69MM in 3Q23.
Net income of $89MM increased by $370MM compared to 3Q22, driven primarily by a higher income tax benefit and lower litigation expense.
The total corporate effective tax rate (ETR) for the quarter was 4%.
Excluding discrete tax benefits and recurring ESG tax credit benefits, the ETR would have been approximately 25%.
The full-year 2023 ETR, excluding the FDIC special assessment and other discrete items, is expected to be approximately 9-10%.
Holds leadership positions including No. 1 in estimated U.S. Retail Deposits, No. 1 in Online and Mobile Banking Functionality, and No. 1 Small Business Lender.
Recognized as Best Bank in North America, Best Consumer Digital Bank in the U.S., and Best Bank in the U.S. for Small and Medium Enterprises.
Certified by J.D. Power for outstanding client satisfaction and ranked No. 1 in Customer Satisfaction for U.S. Retail Banking Advice.
Maintains numerous business leadership positions, including No. 1 on Forbes' Best-in-State Wealth Advisors and Barron's Top 100 Women Financial Advisors lists for 2023.
Recognized for excellence in private banking, personal trust AUM, technology, and philanthropic initiatives.
Holds several leadership positions, including World's Most Innovative Bank (2023) and World's Best Digital Bank.
Awarded for product innovation in cash management for CashPro Mobile, Forecasting, and API.
Maintains relationships with 74% of the Global Fortune 500 and 95% of the U.S. Fortune 1,000.
Holds numerous business leadership awards, including World's Best Bank for Markets and Americas Derivatives House of the Year.
Recognized for leadership in sustainable finance, CLOs, municipal bonds, and equity block trades.
Total credit and debit spend and transactions are both up 4% year-over-year.
The loan portfolio is more balanced and has less inherent risk compared to 4Q09, with a lower concentration in the consumer portfolio and less exposure to unsecured credit and home equity loans.
GWIM loans have more than doubled since 4Q09.
The Commercial Real Estate portfolio is more balanced, with less concentration in construction loans.
CCAR stress test results indicate significantly lower credit losses are expected in a severe downturn compared to the 2009 stress test.
The capital base and liquidity have increased significantly, with ~$77B higher tangible common equity and Global Liquidity Sources about four times higher than in 4Q09.
Since the beginning of 2004, the total Consumer net charge-off rate has averaged 1.6%.
During the financial crisis period (1Q08 to 4Q12), the NCO rate averaged 3.6% and peaked at 6.0% in 3Q09.
In the post-financial crisis period (1Q13 to 3Q23), the NCO rate has averaged a much lower 0.7%.
The total commercial annualized net charge-off (NCO) rate has averaged 49 bps since 1Q07 (29 bps excluding Small Business).
During the financial crisis period (1Q08 to 4Q12), the NCO rate averaged 128 bps (80 bps excluding Small Business).
Post-financial crisis (1Q13 to 3Q23), the NCO rate has averaged a significantly lower 13 bps (8 bps excluding Small Business).
The office portfolio is high quality, with ~75% Class A properties, ~55% origination LTV, and only ~6% NPL to loans.
Reservable criticized exposure in the office portfolio is $5.1B.
Global Liquidity Sources (GLS) include cash and high-quality, liquid, unencumbered securities readily available to meet funding requirements.
Reserve Build (or Release) is calculated by subtracting net charge-offs from the provision for credit losses.
Pretax, pre-provision income (PTPI) is a non-GAAP measure calculated by adding back the provision for credit losses to pretax income.
Interest rate sensitivity reflects the pretax impact to forecasted net interest income from an instantaneous parallel shock to the yield curve.
Revenue figures include net debit valuation adjustments (DVA) on derivatives.
The VaR model uses a historical simulation approach with a 99% confidence level.
Source (A): Estimated U.S. retail deposits based on June 30, 2023 FDIC deposit data.
Source (B): Javelin 2023 Online and Mobile Banking Scorecards.
Source (C): FDIC, 2Q23.
Source (D-F): Global Finance, various dates in 2022 and 2023.
Source (G-H): J.D. Power 2023 studies on Financial Health Support and Retail Banking Advice Satisfaction.
Source (I-Z): Various industry reports and publications including FDIC, Family Wealth Report, Global Private Banking Innovation Award, Euromoney, The Banker, Dealogic, etc.
This presentation contains forward-looking statements that are subject to risks and uncertainties and are not guarantees of future performance.
Forward-looking statements involve expectations about future results, revenues, liquidity, and other financial and business matters.
Actual results may differ materially from those expressed in forward-looking statements.
Key risks include litigation, regulatory actions, discontinuation of reference rates, geopolitical instability, interest rate and inflation impacts, credit losses, and cyberattacks.
The Corporation does not undertake an obligation to update any forward-looking statement.
The information presented is preliminary and based on data available at the time of the earnings presentation.
The presentation may include non-GAAP financial measures; reconciliations are available in the quarterly earnings press release.
Key financial and nonfinancial performance indicators (KPIs) are used by management to assess performance.
Net interest income is also viewed on a fully taxable-equivalent (FTE) basis, which is a non-GAAP measure.
Capital is allocated to business segments based on a methodology considering regulatory and internal risk-based models.
